camera_visible.documentation: Camera in the visible light range

camera_visible.channel.documentation: Set of channels (a front aperture, possibly followed by others, viewing the plasma recorded by one or more detectors e.g. for different wavelength ranges)

camera_visible.channel[:].aperture.documentation: Description of apertures between plasma and the detectors (position, outline shape and orientation)

camera_visible.channel[:].aperture[:].ce.documentation: If geometry_type=2, coordinates of the centre of the circle. If geometry_type=1 or 3, coordinates of the origin of the local coordinate system (X1,X2,X3) describing the plane detector/aperture. This origin is located within the detector/aperture area.
Toroidal angle (oriented counter-clockwise when viewing from above)
Index in the error_description list for "phi"
Index in the error_description list for "r"
Index in the error_description list for "z"

camera_visible.channel[:].aperture[:].ge.documentation: Type of geometry used to describe the surface of the detector or aperture (1:'outline', 2:'circular', 3:'rectangle'). In case of 'outline', the surface is described by an outline of point in a local coordinate system defined by a centre and three unit vectors X1, X2, X3. Note that there is some flexibility here and the data provider should choose the most convenient coordinate system for the object, respecting the definitions of (X1,X2,X3) indicated below. In case of 'circular', the surface is a circle defined by its centre, radius, and normal vector oriented towards the plasma X3.  In case of 'rectangle', the surface is a rectangle defined by its centre, widths in the X1 and X2 directions, and normal vector oriented towards the plasma X3.

camera_visible.channel[:].aperture[:].ou.documentation: Irregular outline of the detector/aperture in the (X1, X2) coordinate system. Do NOT repeat the first point.
Index in the error_description list for "x1"
Index in the error_description list for "x2"

camera_visible.channel[:].aperture[:].ra.documentation: Radius of the circle, used only if geometry_type = 2
Index in the error_description list for "radius"

camera_visible.channel[:].aperture[:].su.documentation: Surface of the detector/aperture, derived from the above geometric data
Index in the error_description list for "surface"

camera_visible.channel[:].aperture[:].x1.documentation: Components of the X1 direction unit vector in the (X,Y,Z) coordinate system, where X is the major radius axis for phi = 0, Y is the major radius axis for phi = pi/2, and Z is the height axis. The X1 vector is more horizontal than X2 (has a smaller abs(Z) component) and oriented in the positive phi direction (counter-clockwise when viewing from above).
Index in the error_description list for "x"
Index in the error_description list for "y"
Index in the error_description list for "z"
Full width of the aperture in the X1 direction, used only if geometry_type = 3
Index in the error_description list for "x1_width"

camera_visible.channel[:].aperture[:].x2.documentation: Components of the X2 direction unit vector in the (X,Y,Z) coordinate system, where X is the major radius axis for phi = 0, Y is the major radius axis for phi = pi/2, and Z is the height axis. The X2 axis is orthonormal so that uX2 = uX3 x uX1.
Index in the error_description list for "x"
Index in the error_description list for "y"
Index in the error_description list for "z"
Full width of the aperture in the X2 direction, used only if geometry_type = 3
Index in the error_description list for "x2_width"

camera_visible.channel[:].aperture[:].x3.documentation: Components of the X3 direction unit vector in the (X,Y,Z) coordinate system, where X is the major radius axis for phi = 0, Y is the major radius axis for phi = pi/2, and Z is the height axis. The X3 axis is normal to the detector/aperture plane and oriented towards the plasma.
Index in the error_description list for "x"
Index in the error_description list for "y"
Index in the error_description list for "z"

camera_visible.channel[:].detector[:].co.documentation: Number of pixel columns in the horizontal direction

Counts to radiance factor, for each pixel of the detector. Includes both the transmission losses in the relay optics and the quantum efficiency of the camera itself, integrated over the wavelength range
Index in the error_description list for "counts_to_radiance"

camera_visible.channel[:].detector[:].ex.documentation: Index in the error_description list for "exposure_time"

camera_visible.channel[:].detector[:].fr.documentation: Raw image (unprocessed) (digital levels). First dimension : line index (horizontal axis). Second dimension: column index (vertical axis).
Radiance image. First dimension : line index (horizontal axis). Second dimension: column index (vertical axis).
Index in the error_description list for "radiance"

camera_visible.channel[:].detector[:].ge.documentation: Description of geometry matrix (ray transfer matrix)
Grid defining the light emission cells
Index in the error_description list for "dim1"
Index in the error_description list for "dim2"
Index in the error_description list for "dim3"

Grid type
1) r_z_phi : Cylindrical r,z,phi grid : r=dim1, z=dim2, phi=dim3
Integer identifier (enumeration index within a list). Private identifier values must be indicated by a negative index.
Interpolated geometry matrix for reflected light

Interpolated Ray Transfer Matrix (RTM, or geometry matrix), which provides transformation of the reflected light from each interpolation knot to the receiver (detector pixel). When convolving with an emission profile, the values must be interpolated to the emission grid and multiplied by the volume of the grid cells. The interpolated matrix is given on an array of interpolation knots of coordinates r, z and phi (third dimension of this array). The first two dimension correspond to the detector pixels : first dimension : line index (horizontal axis); second dimension: column index (vertical axis).
Index in the error_description list for "data"
Toroidal angle (oriented counter-clockwise when viewing from above) of interpolation knots
Index in the error_description list for "phi"
Index in the error_description list for "r"
Index in the error_description list for "z"

Voxel map for geometry matrix. The cells with same number are merged in the computation into a single emission source meta-cell (the voxel). Cells with number -1 are excluded. Voxel count starts from 0.
Number of voxels defined in the voxel_map.

The Ray Transfer Matrix (RTM, or geometry matrix) here provides transformation of the signal from each individual unit light source (voxel) to each pixel of the receiver (detector). The emission profile has [photons.m^-3.s^-1.sr^-1] units and radiance signal has [photons.m^-2.s^-1.sr^-1] units. So the RTM has [m] units. This data is stored in a sparse form, i.e. the array contains only the non-zero element of the Ray transfer matrix. The voxel index corresponding to an element of this array can be found in voxel_indices. The pixel indices corresponding to an element of this array can be found in pixel_indices
Index in the error_description list for "data"

List of pixel indices used in the sparse data array. The first dimension refers to the data array index. The second dimension lists the line index (horizontal axis) in first position, then the column index (vertical axis).
List of voxel indices (defined in the voxel map) used in the sparse data array

The Ray Transfer Matrix (RTM, or geometry matrix) here provides transformation of the signal from each individual unit light source (voxel) to each pixel of the receiver (detector). The emission profile has [photons.m^-3.s^-1.sr^-1] units and radiance signal has [photons.m^-2.s^-1.sr^-1] units. So the RTM has [m] units. This data is stored in a sparse form, i.e. the array contains only the non-zero element of the Ray transfer matrix. The voxel index corresponding to an element of this array can be found in voxel_indices. The pixel indices corresponding to an element of this array can be found in pixel_indices
Index in the error_description list for "data"

List of pixel indices used in the sparse data array. The first dimension refers to the data array index. The second dimension lists the line index (horizontal axis) in first position, then the column index (vertical axis).
List of voxel indices (defined in the voxel map) used in the sparse data array

camera_visible.channel[:].detector[:].li.documentation: Number of pixel lines in the vertical direction

camera_visible.channel[:].detector[:].no.documentation: Detector noise (e.g. read-out noise) (rms counts per second exposure time)
Index in the error_description list for "noise"

camera_visible.channel[:].detector[:].pi.documentation: Alpha angle of each pixel in the horizontal axis
Index in the error_description list for "pixel_to_alpha"
Beta angle of each pixel in the vertical axis
Index in the error_description list for "pixel_to_beta"

camera_visible.channel[:].detector[:].wa.documentation: Lower bound of the detector wavelength range
Index in the error_description list for "wavelength_lower"
Upper bound of the detector wavelength range
Index in the error_description list for "wavelength_upper"

camera_visible.channel[:].fibre_bundle.f.documentation: Individual fibres centres positions in the (X1, X2) coordinate system
Index in the error_description list for "x1"
Index in the error_description list for "x2"
Index in the error_description list for "fibre_radius"

camera_visible.channel[:].fibre_bundle.g.documentation: Geometry of the fibre bundle entrance

If geometry_type=2, coordinates of the centre of the circle. If geometry_type=1 or 3, coordinates of the origin of the local coordinate system (X1,X2,X3) describing the plane detector/aperture. This origin is located within the detector/aperture area.

In case of 'outline', the surface is described by an outline of point in a local coordinate system defined by a centre and three unit vectors X1, X2, X3. Note that there is some flexibility here and the data provider should choose the most convenient coordinate system for the object, respecting the definitions of (X1,X2,X3) indicated below. In case of 'circular', the surface is a circle defined by its centre, radius, and normal vector oriented towards the plasma X3.  In case of 'rectangle', the surface is a rectangle defined by its centre, widths in the X1 and X2 directions, and normal vector oriented towards the plasma X3.

camera_visible.channel[:].optical_elemen.documentation:
Curvature of the surface
1) planar : Planar object, no curvature
2) cylindrical_x1 : Cylindrical in the X1 direction, use x1_curvature
3) cylindrical_x2 : Cylindrical in the X2 direction, use x2_curvature
4) spherical : Spherical : same curvature radius in X1 and X2 directions, indicated in x1_curvature
5) toroidal : Toroidal : x1_curvature in X1 direction and x2_curvature in X2 direction
Integer identifier (enumeration index within a list). Private identifier values must be indicated by a negative index.
Radius of curvature in the X1 direction, to be filled only for curvature_type/index = 2, 4 or 5
Index in the error_description list for "x1_curvature"
Radius of curvature in the X2 direction, to be filled only for curvature_type/index = 3 or 5
Index in the error_description list for "x2_curvature"

Curvature of the surface
1) planar : Planar object, no curvature
2) cylindrical_x1 : Cylindrical in the X1 direction, use x1_curvature
3) cylindrical_x2 : Cylindrical in the X2 direction, use x2_curvature
4) spherical : Spherical : same curvature radius in X1 and X2 directions, indicated in x1_curvature
5) toroidal : Toroidal : x1_curvature in X1 direction and x2_curvature in X2 direction
Integer identifier (enumeration index within a list). Private identifier values must be indicated by a negative index.
Radius of curvature in the X1 direction, to be filled only for curvature_type/index = 2, 4 or 5
Index in the error_description list for "x1_curvature"
Radius of curvature in the X2 direction, to be filled only for curvature_type/index = 3 or 5
Index in the error_description list for "x2_curvature"

Material properties of the optical element
Index in the error_description list for "extinction_coefficient"
Index in the error_description list for "refractive_index"
Roughness parameter of the material. Varies in range [0, 1]. 0 is perfectly specular, 1 is perfectly rough
Index in the error_description list for "roughness"
Index in the error_description list for "transmission_coefficient"

Type of optical element material. In case of 'metal' refractive_index and extinction_coefficient are used. In case of 'dielectric' refractive_index and transmission_coefficient are used.
1) metal : Metal
2) dielectric : Dielectric
Integer identifier (enumeration index within a list). Private identifier values must be indicated by a negative index.
Wavelengths array for refractive_index, extinction_coefficient and transmission_coefficient
Index in the error_description list for "wavelengths"
Distance between front_surface and back_surface along the X3 vector
Index in the error_description list for "thickness"

Type of optical element. In case of 'mirror' and 'diaphragm', the element is described by one 'front_surface'. In case of 'lens', the element is described by 'front_surface' and 'back_surface'.
1) mirror : Mirror
2) lens : Lens
3) diaphragm : Diaphragm
Integer identifier (enumeration index within a list). Private identifier values must be indicated by a negative index.

camera_visible.channel[:].viewing_angle_.documentation: Minimum and maximum values of alpha angle of the field of view, where alpha is the agle between the axis X3 and projection of the chord of view  on the plane X1X3 counted clockwise from the top view of X2 axis. X1, X2, X3 are the ones of the first aperture (i.e. the closest to the plasma).
Index in the error_description list for "viewing_angle_alpha_bounds"

Minimum and maximum values of beta angle of the field of view, where beta is the angle between the axis X3 and projection of the chord of view on the plane X2X3 counted clockwise from the top view of X1 axis. X1, X2, X3 are the ones of the first aperture (i.e. the closest to the plasma).
Index in the error_description list for "viewing_angle_beta_bounds"

camera_visible.code.documentation: Generic decription of the code-specific parameters for the code that has produced this IDS

camera_visible.code.description.documentation: Short description of the software (type, purpose)

camera_visible.code.library.documentation: List of external libraries used by the code that has produced this IDS

camera_visible.code.library[:].descripti.documentation: Short description of the software (type, purpose)

camera_visible.code.library[:].parameter.documentation: List of the code specific parameters in XML format

camera_visible.code.output_flag.documentation: Output flag : 0 means the run is successful, other values mean some difficulty has been encountered, the exact meaning is then code specific. Negative values mean the result shall not be used.

camera_visible.code.parameters.documentation: List of the code specific parameters in XML format

camera_visible.ids_properties.documentation: Interface Data Structure properties. This element identifies the node above as an IDS

camera_visible.ids_properties.comment.documentation: Any comment describing the content of this IDS

camera_visible.ids_properties.creation_d.documentation: Date at which this data has been produced

camera_visible.ids_properties.homogeneou.documentation: This node must be filled (with 0, 1, or 2) for the IDS to be valid. If 1, the time of this IDS is homogeneous, i.e. the time values for this IDS are stored in the time node just below the root of this IDS. If 0, the time values are stored in the various time fields at lower levels in the tree. In the case only constant or static nodes are filled within the IDS, homogeneous_time must be set to 2

camera_visible.ids_properties.name.documentation: User-defined name for this IDS occurrence

camera_visible.ids_properties.occurrence.description: occurrence number [NOTE: this field only exists in OMAS and is not part of the ITER PDM]

camera_visible.ids_properties.occurrence.documentation:
Type of data contained in this occurrence
1) reconstruction : Equilibrium reconstruction
2) prediction_fixed : Equilibrium prediction, fixed boundary
3) prediction_free : Equilibrium prediction, free boundary
4) mapping : Used for mapping equilibrium results from one grid type / resolution to another, or for including variables not present in the first set such as the calculation of magnetic field of other derived parameters
Integer identifier (enumeration index within a list). Private identifier values must be indicated by a negative index.

camera_visible.ids_properties.plugins.documentation: Information about the plugins used to write/read this IDS. This structure is filled automatically by the Access Layer at GET/PUT time, no need to fill it via a user program.

camera_visible.ids_properties.plugins.in.documentation: Plugin infrastructure used to GET the data
Short description of the software (type, purpose)
Plugin infrastructure used to PUT the data
Short description of the software (type, purpose)

camera_visible.ids_properties.plugins.no.documentation: Set of IDS nodes for which a plugin has been applied

Plugins actually used to read back a node (potentially, multiple plugins can be applied, listed in reverse order of application). This information is filled by the plugin infrastructure during the GET operation.
Short description of the software (type, purpose)
List of the code specific parameters in XML format
Path of the node within the IDS, following the syntax given in the link below. If empty, means the plugin applies to the whole IDS.
Plugins used to PUT a node (potentially, multiple plugins can be applied, if so they are listed by order of application)
Short description of the software (type, purpose)
List of the code specific parameters in XML format
Plugins to be used to read back a node (potentially, multiple plugins can be applied, listed in reverse order of application)
Short description of the software (type, purpose)
List of the code specific parameters in XML format

camera_visible.ids_properties.provenance.documentation: Set of IDS nodes for which the provenance is given. The provenance information applies to the whole structure below the IDS node. For documenting provenance information for the whole IDS, set the size of this array of structure to 1 and leave the child "path" node empty
Path of the node within the IDS, following the syntax given in the link below. If empty, means the provenance information applies to the whole IDS.

List of sources used to import or calculate this node, identified as explained below. In case the node is the result of of a calculation / data processing, the source is an input to the process described in the "code" structure at the root of the IDS. The source can be an IDS (identified by a URI or a persitent identifier, see syntax in the link below) or non-IDS data imported directly from an non-IMAS database (identified by the command used to import the source, or the persistent identifier of the data source). Often data are obtained by a chain of processes, however only the last process input are recorded here. The full chain of provenance has then to be reconstructed recursively from the provenance information contained in the data sources.

camera_visible.ids_properties.provider.documentation: Name of the person in charge of producing this data

camera_visible.ids_properties.source.documentation: Source of the data (any comment describing the origin of the data : code, path to diagnostic signals, processing method, ...). Superseeded by the new provenance structure.

camera_visible.ids_properties.version_pu.documentation: Version of the access layer package used to PUT this IDS
Version of Access Layer used to PUT this IDS
Programming language of the Access Layer high level API used to PUT this IDS
Version of Data Dictionary used to PUT this IDS

camera_visible.latency.documentation: Upper bound of the delay between physical information received by the detector and data available on the real-time (RT) network.

camera_visible.latency_error_index.documentation: Index in the error_description list for "latency"
